meeting_annotations.speaker: Caitlin Davis
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I come from a protein folding background to put this in context and I feel like in the folding field if we think about crowding we can predict what's going to happen to proteins based on crowding alone. So crowding stabilizes proteins it stabilizes binding interactions and and so from that perspective for from a well-structured protein we can make pretty good predictions but what we don't understand is how the other parts of the environment are affecting the stability of proteins or predicting how like non-steric interactions are affecting the protein interactions. So I thought this was a nice juxtaposition to what Paul was saying about his specific system.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matthias Heyden
meeting_annotations.transcript: I would I would very much agree with that is very much a point that I wrote down too that we understand crowding in terms of volume exclusion that there is limited volume that usually stabilizes either aggregation or compact folds or stuff like that but we don't understand all the effects of attractive interactions which if you have things which strongly attract each other they will precipitate out of course but in in the cell you are surrounded by a myriad of other potential interaction partners these interactions are not necessarily strong but they're not zero or repulsive either and how they can affect for example biomolecular assembly the formation of complexes and everything is very densely packed so what Paul was mentioning are there any collective dynamic effects like hydrodynamics how do they affect not only the the biomolecular assembly which is a thermodynamic problem but also how things move in the cell dynamically.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Caitlin Davis
meeting_annotations.transcript: And I think maybe crowding and how it affects intrinsically disordered proteins or disordered molecules is is less well understood as well.
